## A Wonderful Evening

Thank you to everyone who came out to the opening night of "Earth & Fire". It was incredible to see so many familiar faces and meet new art lovers.

The dialogue between the ceramics and the wooden sculptures by James Doe created a fantastic tension in the gallery space. We are already discussing a follow-up collaboration for next year.

A Wonderful Evening

Thank you to everyone who came out to the opening night of “Earth & Fire”. It was incredible to see so many familiar faces and meet new art lovers.

The dialogue between the ceramics and the wooden sculptures by James Doe created a fantastic tension in the gallery space. We are already discussing a follow-up collaboration for next year.
Join us for a weekend of wheel throwing.

## Learn the Wheel

We are excited to announce a beginner's intensive weekend workshop. Whether you are a complete novice or looking to refine your centering technique, this workshop will provide hands-on guidance.

**Topics Covered:**
1.  Wedging and clay preparation
2.  Centering on the wheel
3.  Pulling walls and shaping
4.  Trimming and finishing

Spaces are limited to 8 participants. Link in bio to register!

Notes from the kiln and upcoming projects.

## Fresh from the Kiln

We've just unloaded a new firing and the results are promising. The experiment with local clay harvested from the riverbank yielded a rich, terracotta red that works beautifully with the white slip decoration.

Acquisition of the 'Blue Series' by Modern Art London.

## The Blue Series

We are honored to have the entire "Blue Series" acquired by Modern Art London for their permanent collection. This series explored the gradients of cobalt oxide in porcelain.

The pieces will be on display in the West Wing starting next month.

The Blue Series

We are honored to have the entire “Blue Series” acquired by Modern Art London for their permanent collection. This series explored the gradients of cobalt oxide in porcelain.

The pieces will be on display in the West Wing starting next month.
A curated set of large scale vessels for a private residence.

## Architectural Scale

This commission involved creating three large-scale vessels for a minimalist loft in Tribeca. The challenge was to create forms that held their own against the industrial architecture of the space.

The pieces were coiled built over several weeks and fired in a reduction atmosphere to achieve a dark, metallic finish.

Architectural Scale

This commission involved creating three large-scale vessels for a minimalist loft in Tribeca. The challenge was to create forms that held their own against the industrial architecture of the space.

The pieces were coiled built over several weeks and fired in a reduction atmosphere to achieve a dark, metallic finish.
A study in surface treatment and natural glazes.

## Surface and Depth

This collection focuses on the tactile experience of ceramics. Using heavy grog clay bodies and shino glazes, the surface becomes a landscape of its own.

The firing process was done in a wood kiln, introducing ash deposits that create unpredictable and beautiful variations in color and texture.

Surface and Depth

This collection focuses on the tactile experience of ceramics. Using heavy grog clay bodies and shino glazes, the surface becomes a landscape of its own.

The firing process was done in a wood kiln, introducing ash deposits that create unpredictable and beautiful variations in color and texture.
Exploring the simplicity of shape and silence in clay.

## The Essence of Reduction

In this series, I explored the concept of reduction—stripping away the unnecessary to reveal the essential form. The clay is left relatively unadorned, allowing the silhouette to speak for itself.

> "Perfection is achieved, not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away." - Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

The process involved wheel throwing followed by extensive trimming to achieve thin, delicate walls that contradict the visual weight of the material.

The Essence of Reduction

In this series, I explored the concept of reduction—stripping away the unnecessary to reveal the essential form. The clay is left relatively unadorned, allowing the silhouette to speak for itself.

“Perfection is achieved, not when there is nothing more to add, but when there is nothing left to take away.” - Antoine de Saint-Exupéry

The process involved wheel throwing followed by extensive trimming to achieve thin, delicate walls that contradict the visual weight of the material.
Hand-built organic shapes inspired by coastal landscapes.

## Organic Growth

Unlike wheel-thrown pieces, these vessels were built using coil and slab techniques, allowing for asymmetry and organic imperfections. The inspiration comes from the eroded cliffs and stone formations of the coast.

Each piece is unique, with textures created by pressing local stones and shells into the soft clay before firing.

Organic Growth

Unlike wheel-thrown pieces, these vessels were built using coil and slab techniques, allowing for asymmetry and organic imperfections. The inspiration comes from the eroded cliffs and stone formations of the coast.

Each piece is unique, with textures created by pressing local stones and shells into the soft clay before firing.
